key_points: Kyle Rittenhouse's lawyers refute claims linking him to the Proud Boys and white supremacist groups.
Kenosha County Assistant District Attorney Thomas C. Binge filed an affidavit to modify Rittenhouse's bond after seeing him at a bar.
Rittenhouse, accused of killing two and injuring one during Kenosha protests, pleaded not guilty.
Prosecutors note Rittenhouse's interaction with adults singing a Proud Boys anthem and posing with an 'OK' hand gesture at a bar.
Binge's motion aims to restrict Rittenhouse from consuming alcohol, frequenting bars, and associating with white supremacist groups.
Defense attorney Mark Richards denies Rittenhouse's link to any far-right groups and does not oppose bond modification barring association with hate groups.
Richards criticizes the motion as an attempt to insert race into a self-defense case.
Wisconsin law allows individuals aged 18-20 to drink alcohol under parental supervision; Rittenhouse's bar visit didn't violate bond conditions.
Rittenhouse accused of joining right-wing militias during the Kenosha protest, with no evidence found of him following such groups on social media.
Rittenhouse's defense threatens legal action against those accusing him of white supremacy.
spokespersons: Thomas C. Binge (Kenosha County Assistant District Attorney)
